senses.ex: The flight delay was due to bad weather.

Tips.title: Expressing Reason
Tips.description: Use 'due to' to introduce the reason for something.  It's often used before a noun or noun phrase.
Tips.example: The game was cancelled due to heavy rain.

Tips.title: Formal Contexts
Tips.description: 'Due to' is generally considered more formal than 'because of'.
Tips.example: In his report, he stated that the decline in sales was due to several factors.

Tips.title: Avoiding with Verbs
Tips.description: While 'because of' can be used before a verb phrase, 'due to' typically precedes a noun phrase. Avoid using 'due to' directly before a verb.
Tips.example: Incorrect: The party was postponed due to raining. Correct: The party was postponed due to the rain.  OR The party was postponed because of the rain.

because of.wordDefinition: 'Because of' is more common in informal contexts and can be used before both noun phrases and verb phrases. 'Due to' is generally more formal and precedes noun phrases.

owing to.wordDefinition: 'Owing to' is a synonym of 'due to' and is also considered formal.

as a result of.wordDefinition: 'As a result of' is a slightly more formal alternative to 'because of' and 'due to', often used to describe consequences.
